reviews.review_msg: ambivalent.  great readings. poor discussion.

He is a hard and demanding prof. Class participation is a "SACRED DUTY." I got around B - B+ in his classes, but I still thought he was a great prof. He tried to take politics out of the class as much as possible and is "all about history" (Said by a classmate) Contrary to other comments, he is no longer late to class nor does he throw "hissy fits"
He clearly knows his stuff, and is fluent in like 5 languages. He's a freaken hard marker, but a great lecturer. If you don't do your readings however, your screwed :)

Knows his information, and will tell you everything he knows. Good guy, hard to understand what he wants in seminars. DO THE READING, lost without it. Will go into GREAT detail after every question or input by another class member.

Thought provoking reading material and response questions albeit he doesnt lead seminars in the traditional SFU way. He may seem evasive at first but he is extremely helpful and approachable. Came out of the class with a new interest in M/E history. Great Prof!

Andrea is literally the sweetest. She is so soft spoken, caring, and encouraging. Assignments were fairly easy and she gives good feedback. There was a lot of reading but if youre interested in the topic then its a super rewarding course. Take her if you can!!!

I've taken 3 upper level courses with her,highly recommend her. Is a fair marker and gives thorough feedback on work. She's responsive to student's concerns and encouraging. She assigns interesting material especially if you like north american history, migration and borderlands history. She is very willing to help students.
i would not take another class with her. if you voice an opinion incongruent with hers, she will abruptly dismiss yours. lectures are dreadful!

This man is very enthusiastic about the subject matter, and has great suggestions for papers if you ask him. Lectures are disorganised, but can be informative. I would recommend  actually paying attention and making an effort: your term paper will thank you for it. I'd take him again.
Amazing professor. Goes out of his way to help students. Lectures are fun & engaging. Best prof I've met at SFU. If you don't enjoy history, his classes will definitely change your mind!

Good professor, lost of reading and writing for THIS course. If you can handle reading about 30+ pages a week than you'll be okay. Class discussions are critical, so come prepared. Attendance is required to pass this class. And lastly you must complete all the assignments or he'll give you an incomplete. Good guy but one tough and demanding class.

Hands down the best & most human history prof I've had @ SFU. Take the "Italian Films, Italian Histories" seminar if you're open to new (but challenging) ways of looking at history & can handle the workload. You'll work a ton, but it's well worth the trouble. I'll never watch films the same way again, and that's a good thing.

People, this is the question: do you want to learn something? If yes, take a course with Garfinkel. If you work hard everything will be OK. If you don't, things will not work out so well. It is that simple. Bottom line, your writing will improve. I strongly recommend PG.

I have never had a prof who is more passionate and knowledgeable about their subject and who cares more about his students than Professore. That doesn't mean his seminars are easy. Expect to be challenged. He makes you work for your marks, but it's well worth the effort.
Why can't we get more profs like him? His Italian film/Italian history class was the best class I took at SFU.
Awesome prof. Excellent discussions and films, fair amounts of reading, a bit too much writing. Expectations for writing are high, but going for extra help def. paid off for me.

Great prof, funny guy. Seminar discussions are super high quality. I like the film component, too. Makes the seminars much more interesting and enjoyable, not just your usual primary/secondary texts or research papers. But it's true: with him, there's no such thing as an easy A.

Garfinkel is the best. He runs a great seminar (I've done 2), and his Italy courses are fascinating. I don't recommend if your main/only concern is GPA (see below). You'll love him if you're interested in learning, esp. writing. I became a MUCH better writer thanks to him. His comments are xtremely helpful and more thorough than any I've had at SFU

Garfinkel is a terrific teacher and a funny, personable guy. Seminars are interesting and entertaining. Expect to be challenged and pushed, and don't expect easy marks. He REALLY stresses writing (more than any prof I've had), so if you're not a good writer, or don't try to get better in a hurry, you're going to have a hard time.

Great Prof! He is a very fair marker and the readings were not excessive for a 400-level course (100-120 pages a week). If you do the assigned readings and assignments on time and attend the lectures/seminars than an A can be obtained. In short, hard work is the only way to an A. Highly recommended!

Sometimes his expectations are a little unclear (or change), but he is an extremely knowledgable prof who wants to see his students do well. Be prepared to participate and keep up with the readings, but also enjoy the high level of discussion his classes usually contain. A pretty solid prof on the whole.

Stuart Parker: a debonair gentleman of dashing charm. His intellect and wit kept me perched on the edge of my seat. Insightful as only a person of his experienced and studied wisdom can be, I can recommend no other professor so highly.

Great prof, very intelligent guy with broad interests. Course was on the History of the Indian Ocean, so mostly about East Africa, Arabia and India. Kind of an interdisciplinary feel to his approach. You will have to do the readings. He has a slight fondness for amusing crackpot theories.

I enjoyed her class very much. Active participation in daily discussion is key.  Lots of reading and a few movies but overall a very interesting course.  I would definitely take her class again.  Two essays in which your overall grade depends heavily on 25% and 50% but no final.
No Comments
No Comments

Paul is nice and really interested in Middle Eastern history but his teaching style can be somewhat ineffective and boring. He asks very specific questions & continues trying to drag it out of students even when it is clear no one knows the answer. Very helpful with assignments if you go and see him in his office hours. Overall a good prof.
Fantastic professor. Clearly cares deeply about the material and her students, was always very accessible for any extra help and would go out of her way to give it.  Also had a great sense of humour.
